Ficarra et al [2] have made 11 suggestions regarding urological surgeries during the 12 COVID-19 pandemic. However, the authors focused on all 13 urological pathologies and reported information from Italy, 14 a country that seemed to be the epicenter of the pandemic 15 in Europe [2] . Regarding eye protection, 25.5% started using goggles, 21.3% 47 were already using goggles, and 34% did not shift to the use 48 of goggles as part of their pandemic response. immediately after the first case report on COVID-19.

BIBREF5.title: Retrograde 145 intrarenal surgery with combined spinal-epidural vs general anes

FIGREF1.text: 16 perspective on how the routine practice patterns of expert 17 European endourologists changed (or adapted) during the 18 COVID-19 pandemic via a survey. By focusing on expert 19 experience coming from the field, we aimed to provide an 20 algorithm to guide the management of urinary stone 21 disease during this unprecedented time of extraordinary 22 stress on the global endourology community. 23 An online survey composed of 31 questions (Supple-24 mentary material) using the web-based Survey-Monkey 25 system (Palo Alto, CA) was circulated primarily to authors 26 who were in the EULIS working groups, whose main areas of 27 expertise was urinary stone disease, and who had contrib-28 uted to the literature to date. Among 98 experts approached, 29 60 physicians (61.2%) responded.

FIGREF3.text: The majority of the experts (89.4%) tended to change 40 their treatment strategy for an emergency patient with

FIGREF5.text: before the pandemic. From an anesthesiology 53 point of view, routine thorax computed tomography (CT) 54 was requested 24 h before surgery by 27.7% of the experts, 55 whereas, 61.7% requested thorax CT in the case of COVID-19 56 suspicion. Some 34% of the respondents preferred spinal 57 anesthesia instead of general anesthesia, whereas 17% 58 continued with spinal anesthesia as used before the 59 pandemic (Fig. 1C), possibly because of the well-known 60 safety of spinal anesthesia in stone surgery [3]. Unless 61 contraindicated, we think that endourologists may prefer 62 regional anesthesia during the COVID-19 pandemic, 63 depending on their hospital conditions. 64 Nearly half of the respondents (48.9%) stated that COVID-65 19 patients have been hospitalized in their departments, 66 with approximately 40% taking an active role in evaluating 67 respiratory symptoms in these patients (Fig. 1D). Therefore, 68 it is obvious that although not specializing in the manage-69 ment of contagious diseases, all health care staff including 70 doctors specializing in other disciplines have been obliged 71 to deal with the pandemic. More than 85% of the 72 participants reported a decrease of >50% in the workload 73 of outpatient clinics. Routine treatment protocols for stone 74 management were reported as altered by 91.3% of the 75 experts. Changes in routine treatment protocols were 76 further investigated in the questionnaire for certain clinical 77 situations. For management of stones of <2 cm and 2-3 cm 78 in size, 31.9% and 27.6% of the participants, respectively, 79 stated that they would prefer a conservative approach until 80 the pandemic settles. In addition, approximately two-thirds 81 stated that they would postpone any auxiliary procedure 82 because of the COVID-19 pandemic and 51% stated that they 83 would discharge patients on the same day or within 24 h 84 postoperatively. 85 Another important aspect is emergency department 86 admission of stone patients. Emergency physicians encoun-87 ter stone patients with more severe conditions such as colic 88 pain, acute renal failure, and pyelonephritis. The survey 89 outlined that emergency department management of stone 90 patients was also altered in more than 90% of cases during this article in press as: Tefik T, et al. FIGREF7.text: emergent urolithiasis cases to other specialized COVID-19 99 centers. While timely management of these cases in the 100 emergency department is crucial, clinical controversies 101 arise if these patients are also suspicious for COVID-19. A 102 possible scenario of a patient presenting to the emergency 103 department with severe colic pain, fever, and cough would 104 be a real dilemma for physicians. In the survey, nearly 90% of 105 the participants stated that they would change the 106 treatment strategy for an emergency case when the patient 107 is positive for COVID-19. Therefore, clinical algorithms for 108 cases presenting with renal obstruction, urinary tract 109 infection, and acute renal failure would be helpful 110 (Fig. 2). Changes in sterilization strategies during the 111 COVID-19 pandemic were also included in the question-112 naire: only 34.8% of the respondents did change their 113 routine strategy for sterilization. This may be because of 114 either a lack of knowledge on the risk of urine-based 115 dissemination of viral RNA or a lack of modification of 116 sterilization strategies in hospitals in the short time117

FIGREF8.text: ago and has gained momentum, and our survey 120 was carried out during this critical period. When faced with 121 such an unexpected situation, urologists, like other 122 physicians, tend to use all of the resources available in 123 their web-based environment, such as European Associa-124 tion of Urology COVID-19 resources for urologists, the 125 American Urological Association coronavirus disease 126 2019 information center, and social media. The COVID-19 127 pandemic has led to significant changes in the practice 128 patterns of endourologists for the management of urinary 129 stone disease. Given the risk of novel viral pandemics in the 130 future, the endourology community should be aware of 131 possible alterations in clinical practice. Clinical algorithms 132 may serve as a useful guide in adapting to these changes in 133 time and in managing patients with urinary calculi safely 134 and successfully.
